div1.p: J.H. Andrus Dies; Army Fever Hero

div1.head: Newspaper clipping, [March 1918]
div1.p:
J. H. ANDRUS DIES;
ARMY FEVER HERO

John Hewitt Andrus, of 805 Cooper
st., Camden, who was awarded a Con-
gressional Medal of Honor for sub-
mitting to injection of yellow fever
germs in 1901 when physicians sought
to determine the source of the dis-
ease, died in the Philadelphia Naval
Hospital yesterday at the age of 62.

Mr. Andrus enlisted in the Army in
1899, was transferred to the Hospi-
tal Corps the following year, and dur-
ing the World War organized the
New Jersey State Militia Reserves,
commanding the group with the rank
of major.

He was associated with the R. M.
Hollingshead Co. in Camden for 23
years, and was advertising manager
for the firm.

Forty-one years ago, Mr. Andrus
was one of 16 or 17 Army volunteers
who were inoculated with yellow fever
germs during the efforts by Army
doctors to prove that mosquitoes
transmitted the dread “yellow jack”
which had caused such havoc among
troops during the Spanish-American
War. Mr. Andrus hovered between
life and death for months before re-
covering.

Surviving are his son, Dr. David L.
Andrus, with whom he lived; his
wife, Mrs. Anna L. Andrus; two
brothers, Vernon B. Andrus, of Col-
lingswood, and Chester J. Andrus, of
Camden, and a sister, Mrs. Mary
Goodwin, of Pittsburgh. Funeral
services will be held Monday at 2 P
M. at 408 Cooper st., Camben.
